page.title: 7.17.0: Lesson Overview
page.contents:
In this lesson, you will determine what expressions would produce graphs with particular vertices. We will look more closely at how changing the \(h\) and the \(k\) in a quadratic expression of the form \(a(x−h)^2+k\) translates the graph, and recall that the coefficient \(a\) affects the direction of the opening of a parabola.

When you finish this lesson, you will be able to:

  • Describe how changing a number in the vertex form of a quadratic function affects its graph.

Here are the activities that will help you reach those goals:

  • 7.17.1: Quadratic Expressions in Different Forms
  • 7.17.2: Modify Expressions to Translate Graphs
    • 7.17.2: Self Check
    • 7.17.2: Additional Resources
  • 7.17.3: Changing the Parameters of a Quadratic Expression
    • 7.17.3: Self Check
    • 7.17.3: Additional Resources
  • 7.17.4: Transforming the Parent Function
  • 7.17.5: Equations of Graph Translations

After that, you’ll practice and review.

  • 7.17.6: Practice
  • 7.17.7: Lesson Summary

page.title: 7.17.1: Quadratic Expressions in Different Forms
page.contents:
Warm Up (5 minutes)

In this warm up, students revisit quadratic expressions in different forms and what the expressions reveal about the graphs that represent them. They match equations and graphs representing two quadratic functions. The axes of the graphs are unlabeled, so students need to reason abstractly about the parameters in the expressions and the features of the graphs.

Launch

Encourage and support opportunities for peer interactions. Invite students to talk about their ideas with a partner before writing them down. 

Student Activity


Here are graphs representing the functions \(f\) and \(g\) given by \(f(x)=x(x+6)\) and \(g(x)=x(x+6)+4\).


  1. Which graph represents \(f(x)=x(x+6)\)? How do you know?

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to compare your work.

Compare your Answer:

The lower graph (which goes through the origin) is the graph of \(f\). 

  • The value of \(g\) is always 4 greater than the value of \(f\), no matter which value of \(x\) we choose.
  • Rewriting the equation in standard form gives \(f(x)=x^2+6x\). This form shows that the \(y\)-intercept of the graph representing \(f\) is \((0,0)\).
  • The expression that defines function \(f\) is in factored form. It shows that the two \(x\)-intercepts are \((0,0)\) and \((-6,0)\).

  1. Which graph represents \(g(x)=x(x+6)+4\)? How do you know?

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to compare your work.

Compare your Answer:

Answer: The lower graph (which goes through the origin) is the graph of \(f\) and the upper one is the graph of \(g\).  

  • The value of \(g\) is always 4 greater than the value of \(f\), no matter which value of \(x\) we choose.
  • Rewriting the equation in standard form gives \(g(x)=x^2+6x+4\).This form shows that the \(y\)-intercept of the graph representing \(g\) is \((0,4)\).

  1. Where does the graph of \(f\) meet the \(x\)-axis? Explain how you know.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(x=-6\) and \(x=0\), because these are the two values of \(x\) that make \(x(x+6)\)  equal to 0.

page.title: 7.17.2: Modify Expressions to Translate Graphs
page.contents:
Activity

  1. How would you change the equation \(y=x^2\) so that the vertex of the graph of the new equation is located at the following coordinates and the graph opens as described?

    1. \((0,11)\), opens up

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to compare your work.

Compare your Answer:

\(y=x^2+11\)


    1. \((7,11)\), opens up

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to compare your work.

Compare your Answer:

Answer: \(y=(x−7)^2+11\)


    1. \((7,-3)\), opens down

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to compare your work.

Compare your Answer:

Answer: \(y=-1(x−7)^2−3\)



  1. Use the graphing tool or technology outside the course. Verify your predictions. 

Select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your Answer:

  1. Kiran graphed the equation \(y=x^2+1\) and noticed that the vertex is at \((0,1)\). He changed the equation to \(y=(x−3)^2+1\) and saw that the graph shifted 3 units to the right and the vertex is now at \((3,1)\).

    Next, he graphed the equation \(y=x^2+2x+1\) and observed that the vertex is at \((-1,0)\). Kiran thought, "If I change the squared term \(x^2\) to \((x−5)^2\), the graph will move 5 units to the right and the vertex will be at \((4,0)\)."
    1. Do you agree with Kiran? 

Correct! Disagree

Incorrect. The correct answer is Disagree.


    1. Explain or show your reasoning why you agree or disagree with Kiran.

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to compare your work.

Compare your Answer:

You should disagree with Kiran.

  • The vertex of the graph of the original equation \(y=x^2+2x+1\) is at \((-1,0)\). The vertex of \(y=(x−5)^2+2x+1\) is at \((4,10)\).
  • Evaluating \(y=(x−5)^2+2x+1\) at \(x = 4\) gives \(y=10\), not \(y=0\).
  • The original equation is not in vertex form, so changing \(x^2\) into \((x−5)^2\) does not change the location of the vertex 5 units to the right.

page.title: 7.17.2: Self Check
page.contents: What transformations and shifts need to be made to change \(y=x^2\) to \(y=-(x+5)^2-10\)?

answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: To move the graph to the right, 5 would have to be added to \(x\). Also, notice the coefficient of the squared term is negative. The answer is it reflects over the \(x\)-axis, moves left 5, and down 10.
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The equation leads with a negative. The answer is it reflects over the \(x\)-axis, moves left 5, and down 10.

answer.answer_text: Reflect over the \(x\)-axis, left 5, and down 10
answer.response: That’s correct! Check yourself: The negative in the front causes the parabola to reflect over the \(x\)-axis. The vertex will be at \((-5, -10)\) so the graph of \(y=x^2\) shifts left 5 and down 10.

answer.answer_text: Reflect over the \(x\)-axis, left 5, and up 10
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The constant term is negative, so the graph shifts down. The answer is it reflects over the \(x\)-axis, moves left 5, and down 10.

answer.answer_text: I am not sure.

page.title: 7.17.2: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Transforming Graphs of Quadratics

The graphs of \(y=x^2\), \(y=x^2+12\), and \(y=(x+3)^2\) all have the same shape but their locations are different. The graph that represents \(y=x^2\) has its vertex at \((0, 0)\).

Notice that adding 12 to \(x^2\) raises the graph by 12 units, so the vertex of that graph is at \((0, 12)\). Replacing \(x^2\) with \((x+3)^2\) shifts the graph 3 units to the left, so the vertex is now at \((-3, 0)\).

We can also shift a graph both horizontally and vertically.

The graph that represents \(y=(x+3)^2 +12\) will look like that for \(y=x^2\) but it will be shifted 12 units up and 3 units to the left. Its vertex is at \((-3, 12)\).

The graph representing the equation \(y=-(x+3)^2+12\) has the same vertex at \((-3, 12)\), but because the squared term \((x+3)^2\) is multiplied by a negative number, the graph is flipped over horizontally, so that it opens downward.

Try It: Transforming Graphs of Quadratics


What transformations and shifts need to be made to change \(y=x^2\) to \(y=-(x-2)^2+7\)?

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to compare your work.

Here is how to determine the transformations needed:

Step 1
Identify the vertex of the new function.
\((2, 7)\)

Step 2
Identify the shifts needed to go from the origin \((0,0)\) to the new vertex.
Right 2, up 7

Step 3
Ask: Does the parabola open up or down? Does it reflect over the \(x\)-axis?
Opens down since the equation leads with a negative. Reflects over the \(x\)-axis.

The transformations needed are right 2, up 7, and a reflection over the \(x\)-axis.

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 7.17.3: Changing the Parameters of a Quadratic Expression
page.contents:
Activity

Mai is learning to create computer animation by programming. In one part of her animation, she uses a quadratic function to model the path of the main character, an animated peanut, jumping over a wall.

Mai uses the equation \(y=-0.1(x−h)^2+k\) to represent the path of the jump. \(y\) represents the height of the peanut as a function of the horizontal distance it travels, \(x\).

On the screen, the base of the wall is located at \((22,0)\), with the top of the wall at \((22,4.5)\). The dashed curve in the picture shows the graph of one equation Mai tried, where the peanut fails to make it over the wall.

  1. What is the value of \(h\) in this equation?

Enter your answer here. 

Correct!

The correct answer is \(h=18\).

  1. What is the value of \(k\) in this equation?

Enter your answer here. 

Correct!

The correct answer is \(k=5\).


  1. Starting with Mai's equation, choose values for \(h\) and \(k\) that will guarantee the peanut stays on the screen but also makes it over the wall. Be prepared to explain your reasoning.

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to compare your work.

Compare your Answer:

  • Use 22 for \(h\). Because \(h\) is the \(x\)-coordinate of the highest point of the jump, if that point is directly over the wall and the \(k\)-value remains at 5, then the peanut would clear the wall. So the new equation would be \(y=-0.1(x−22)^2+5\).
  • Change the value of \(k\), which is the vertical coordinate of the vertex, to 7 so that the vertex is at \((18,7)\) and there is still enough vertical distance to clear the 4.5-unit-tall wall when \(x\) is 22. The new equation would be \(y=-0.1(x−18)^2+7\).

Video: Changing the Parameters of a Quadratic Expression

Watch the following video to learn more about changing the parameters of a quadratic expression.

page.title: 7.17.3: Self Check
page.contents:
Cash kicked a football off a tee. The path of the football is shown below and represented by the function \(f(x)=-0 .02(x-h)^2+k\), where \(x\) represents the horizontal distance and \(f(x)\) represents the height.

Find the vertex and its meaning.

answer.answer_text: \((0,1)\), the ball was kicked from a height of 1 foot.
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This is the starting height. You want the vertex, which represents the maximum height. The answer is \((14,5)\), the football hit its highest height of 5 feet after traveling 14 feet.

answer.answer_text: \((14,5)\), the football hit its highest height of 5 feet after traveling 14 feet.
answer.response: That’s correct! Check yourself: The \(x\)-coordinate is the horizontal distance and the \(y\)-coordinate is the height.

answer.answer_text: \((14,5)\) the football hit its highest height of 14 feet after traveling 5 feet.
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The \(y\)-value is the height. The answer is \((14,5)\), the football hit its highest height of 5 feet after traveling 14 feet.

answer.answer_text: \((30, 0)\), the football travels 30 feet before hitting the ground.
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This is how far it traveled before landing. You are looking for the vertex to find the maximum height. The answer is \((14,5)\), the football hit its highest height of 5 feet after traveling 14 feet.

answer.answer_text: I am not sure.

page.title: 7.17.3: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Determining the Vertex From a Graph

Zaren made a paper football for a game at indoor recess and flicked it in the air from a table. The path of the paper football is shown below and represented by the function \(f(x)=-0 .02(x-h)^2+k\).

Find the value of the vertex and its meaning:

The peak of the graph is at \((17,3)\). This means the maximum horizontal distance traveled was 17 inches when the height of the object was 3 inches.

Try It: Determining the Vertex From a Graph


The revenue made from a high school play is shown in the graph above. Find the vertex and tell what it means in this situation.

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to compare your work.

Here is how to find the vertex and determine its meaning:

The peak of the graph is at \((15, 1100)\). This means that the maximum revenue is $1100 when the ticket price is $15.

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 7.17.4: Transforming the Parent Function
page.contents:
Optional Activity

Do you see two "eyes" and a smiling "mouth" on the graph? The three arcs on the graph all represent quadratic functions that were initially defined by \(y=x^2\), but whose equations were later modified.


  1. Write an equation to represent the smile in the smiley face.

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to compare your work.

Compare your Answer:

The mouth can be given by \(y=x^2+10\) because it is the graph of \(y=x^2\)  shifted 10 units upward. 


  1. Write an equation to represent the left eye in the smiley face.

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to compare your work.

Compare your Answer:

The left eye can be given by \(y=-(x+2)^2+50\) because the vertex is located at \((-2,50)\) and it opens downward.


  1. Write an equation to represent the right eye in the smiley face.

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to compare your work.

Compare your Answer:

The right eye can be given by \(y=-(x−2)^2+50\) because the vertex is located at \((2,50)\) and it opens downward.


  1. What is the domain for the mouth?

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to compare your work.

Compare your Answer:

For the mouth, the domain is \(-4 \leq x \leq 4\).


  1. What is the domain for the left eye?

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to compare your work.

Compare your Answer:

For the left eye, the domain is \(-3 \leq x \leq -1\) .


  1. What is the domain for the right eye?

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to compare your work.

Compare your Answer:

For the right eye, the domain is \(1 \leq x \leq 3\) .

page.title: 7.17.5: Equations of Graph Translations
page.contents:
Cool Down Activity


  1. Here is a graph that represents \(y=x^2\). 

Use the graphing tool or technology outside the course. On the same coordinate plane, sketch a graph that represents \(y=(x−6)^2+10\). 

Then select the Solution button to compare your work.

Compare your Answer:

A graph the same shape as \(y=x^2\) but shifted 6 units to the right and 10 units upward. Its vertex is at \((6,10)\).


  1. The graph representing \(y=x^2\) is shifted 2 units to the left, 10 units down, and flipped so that it opens downward, as shown. 

Which equation defines this curve?

Correct! \(y=-(x+2)^2−10\)

The correct answer is \(y=-(x+2)^2−10\)

page.title: 7.17.6: Practice
page.contents:
Complete the following questions to practice the skills you have learned in this lesson.

  1. Here is the graph of quadratic function \(f\).

Andre uses the expression \((x−5)^2+7\) to define \(f\).

Noah uses the expression \((x+5)^2−7\) to define \(f\).

Do you agree with either of them? 

Correct! No. The vertex of the graph is (5,-7). The graph of Andre’s function would have a vertex at (5,7), and the graph of Noah’s function would have a vertex at (-5,-7).

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 7.17.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is No. The vertex of the graph is (5,-7). The graph of Andre’s function would have a vertex at (5,7), and the graph of Noah’s function would have a vertex at (-5,-7). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Here are the graphs of \(y=x^2\), \(y=x^2−5\), and \(y=(x+2)^2−8\).

    1. How do the three graphs compare?

Correct! The shape is the same but they are in different locations.

Try again. Why don't you go back to activity 7.17.2 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is: The shape is the same but they are in different locations. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. Compare the graphs of \(y=x^2\) and \(y=x^2−5\). What role does the -5 play in the comparison?

Correct! Subtracting 5 from the squared term shifts the graph down by 5 units.

Try again. Why don't you go back to activity 7.17.2 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is: Subtracting 5 from the squared term shifts the graph down by 5 units. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. Compare the graphs of \(y=x^2\) and \(y=(x+2)^2−8\). What roles do the \(+2\) and \(-8\) play in the comparison?

Correct! Adding 2 to \(x\) before squaring shifts the graph of \(y=x^2\) to the left by 2 units and subtracting 8 from the squared term shifts the graph down by 8 units.

Try again. Why don't you go back to activity 7.17.2 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is: Adding 2 to \(x\) before squaring shifts the graph of \(y=x^2\) to the left by 2 units and subtracting 8 from the squared term shifts the graph down by 8 units. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Select all the equations with a graph whose vertex has both a positive \(x\) and a positive \(y\).

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 7.17.2–7.17.5. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answers are: \(y=(x−3)^2+2, y=-(x−4)^2+3, y=-2(x−3)^2+1\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Which equation represents the graph shown?

Correct! \(y=-(x+7)^2+3\)

Try again. Why don't you go back to activity 7.17.5 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(y=-(x+7)^2+3\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. The graph representing \(y=x^2\) is shifted 4 units to the left, 16 units down, and flipped so it opens downward (reflects over the \(x\)-axis). Which equation defines the curve?

Correct! \(y=-(x+4)^2-16\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 7.17.5. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(y=-(x+4)^2-16\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

page.title: 7.17.7: Lesson Summary
page.contents:
In this lesson, you learned how to:

  • Describe how changing a number in the vertex form of a quadratic function affects its graph.

Here are the activities that helped you reach those goals:

  • 7.17.1: Quadratic Expressions in Different Forms
    • In this activity, you matched graphs with their equations by comparing values.
  • 7.17.2: Modify Expressions to Translate Graphs
    • In this activity, you shifted graphs by changing the vertex and writing the correct vertex form given the vertex and the direction of the parabola opening.
    • 7.17.2: Self Check
    • 7.17.2: Additional Resources
  • 7.17.3: Changing the Parameters of a Quadratic Expression
    • In this activity, you changed parameters that found the equation needed to represent the context given. You found the equation of the parabola that modeled the path a peanut needed to take to jump over the wall in a simulation.
    • 7.17.3: Self Check
    • 7.17.3: Additional Resources
  • 7.17.4: Transforming the Parent Function
    • In this optional activity, you were given pieces of parabolas and worked to find the equation of each piece and justify your reasoning.
  • 7.17.5: Equations of Graph Translations
    • In this activity, you looked at both graphs and equations and declared the translations that were made from the parent function \(f(x)=x^2\) to the new equation.

After these activities, you completed the following practice:

  • 7.17.6: Practice

Checking In

On a scale of 1 to 5, how confident do you feel about the learning goals of this lesson?

Correct!

If you’ve answered 3 or less, be sure to reach out to your teacher before starting the next lesson.
